b'"I have long dreamt of capturing an image that brings together the inspiration of Wyoming\xe2\x80\x99s wildlife and landscapes in harmony. After spending nearly every day this fall shooting in Grand Teton and Yellowstone, I became very familiar with the moose in the area and their daily habits: hungry in the mornings, lazy in the day, and thirsty in the evenings. One late afternoon, I set out to a creek where several bull moose were hanging out frequently. As I arrived, the valley basking in a golden glow, the moose were off in the distance but slowly marching my way in the fading afternoon light. Not wanting to disturb their peace, I decided to get in the water and wait patiently hoping for a dream opportunity. And then, right as the sun cast its last rays of light, a bull moose peacefully came down towards the creek where I shivered in my soaking wet boots. He posed majestically with the Grand Teton towering behind, as if he knew I was taking his picture. Moments of magic." - @arthurlefo

b'"On a trip through southern Alberta I came across a beautiful lake with a mirrored reflection and some nice evening light. I attempted to create a wide-angle landscape shot, but with a rather dull foreground, and lack of interest in the sky, the final image wasn't doing the scene justice. Instead I switched to a longer focal length and pulled in the far shore. When your foreground lacks interest, switching to a telephoto lens will help emphasize details in the distant surroundings that you may not be able to get to. I will regularly use this approach when the sky lacks interest as well." - Olympus Visionary @creativeislandphoto

b'"When shooting the aurora, I like to use the Live Bulb feature and hook up my camera to my phone so I can see the framing of my shot. Then once I get the framing how I want it, I play with the settings. I\xe2\x80\x99ve learned there is no perfect way to capture Lady Aurora and I love the process of playing with my settings. Sometimes I want more stars so I go with a longer exposure, but if she is moving fast I bump up my ISO and go with a 3-5 second exposure. A tripod is super important and having my camera connected to my phone lets me try different settings and styles until I\xe2\x80\x99m happy. The most important thing when trying to capture the aurora is to make sure you aren\xe2\x80\x99t just looking through your lens, don\xe2\x80\x99t forget to look up and take in the magic with your own eyes!" - @ilauraexplora

b'"I decided to spend the day in search of one of my dream subjects, the elusive Great Gray Owl. Great Gray Owls are the largest species of owl in the world, but their size does not make them any easier to spot. Their camouflage is second to none, it can be almost impossible to spot one of these birds of prey when they\xe2\x80\x99re not in flight. I found this owl actively hunting, swooping from tree to tree as silent as a ghost. While the owl hunted, the weather changed quickly from heavy snow, to rain, to almost-sun, and back again. Despite the rapidly changing weather and poor light conditions, the new 150-400mm had no issue pulling accurate autofocus. By opting not to bring a tripod I was free to move and change positions quickly while anticipating where I needed to stand to photograph the owl. I relied completely on the combined image stabilization of the lens and my E-M1 Mark III while shooting. The images came out pin sharp, which made me feel pretty happy about my decision to pass on bringing a tripod along." - Olympus Explorer @brookelittlebear

b'"Water drops are one of my favorite subjects to capture.  When I am out looking for wildlife on my local pond in New Hampshire, I always carry my tiny 60mm macro lens with me. The other day, while out on a morning walk, I noticed a spiderweb that looked like a lace collar. It\xe2\x80\x99s funny how you see a subject, get excited, and forget about the composition and background. So, I took a few steps back and began looking for a better angle.  All the leaves around me were still covered with morning dew and the light was piercing through the forest.  I repositioned myself and got lower to the ground so I could get a nice bokeh behind the ornament spider web.  After a few tries, I pushed my ISO and managed to get this bokeh at F7.1 to keep all the pearls in focus. I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I could have gotten this shot with another camera, as I probably would not have had the clearance to do so without digging a hole in the ground to place my camera. Thanks to my Olympus gear, I can be free to find angles, and to carry gear I would not have otherwise.  Now I just have to worry about finding the right angle to take my shot." - #TheBreakFreeProgram's @emilietalpin

Having a camera set up that is small enough that I can stick it in my hoodie pocket while I climb and yet long enough to position me far enough away from my subjects that they didn't even notice my presence is amazing. b'"Underwater the color quickly fades, so you need to get really close to your subjects and bring as much light into the scene as possible. My recommendation for shooting your Olympus camera underwater would be to set your shutter speed to the maximum sync speed of your flash (1/250 sec), set your ISO to 200 for the most dynamic range and choose a small aperture (F5.6-F8) for the biggest depth of field without diffraction. Approach your subject carefully and slow, try to stay shallow and always shoot up to get the beautiful surface and possibly some sunstars into your background. b'"Almost all of the Olympus cameras and lenses make it very easy to switch from autofocus to manual focus mode. Any time you need precise control over focus, manual focus is your best bet. For me, a working example would be when I am using Pro Capture Mode to photograph birds landing on and taking off from a perch. I set a focus target on the perch where I think the bird will land. I switch to manual focus and then aim at the target, lock in my focus and then I forget about it. I am going to be pressing the shutter button when birds enter the plane of focus. Since birds move quickly and change direction quickly, and since there is always a potential for the background to confuse the autofocus in those fast-moving situations, I prefer manual focus."
